item.title: Memories of Bishan Bedi — a man of integrity, wisdom and wit
item.description: The article reflects on Bishan Singh Bedi, a former Indian cricketer who was known for his integrity and his love for the game. Despite his outspoken nature and disregard for diplomacy, Bedi's ideas stemmed from a place of purity and concern. He was a traditionalist who prioritized cricket itself rather than its administrators. Bedi's bowling was admired for its grace and seemingly effortless style, making him one of the finest left-arm spinners of all time. Beyond his impressive statistics, Bedi brought joy to the game and had a positive outlook on life. The article concludes by highlighting Bedi's special relationships with those he met and his gratitude for the game that shaped his life.

item.title: ICC World Cup | It takes more than just teams to make a match; fans are important too
item.description: The article discusses India's performance in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 and criticizes the country for denying visas to fans from Pakistan. It highlights the churlishness displayed by India and suggests that sport can divide people if the government wants it to. The article also mentions the historical tensions between India and Pakistan and the taunting that occurs between fans of both countries. It points out the irony of the authorities loving an India-Pakistan cricket match despite their animosity towards Pakistan. The article concludes by mentioning India's bid for the 2036 Olympics and the need to promote unity and inclusivity.

item.title: The Israel model, and Indian realities | Political Line
item.description: This article discusses the challenges faced by countries with diverse ethnic and religious groups in managing conflicting views and maintaining unity. It refers to the recent violence between Hamas and Israel and how it serves as a pointer for nations dealing with similar challenges. The article also highlights the view in India that a strong state promotes national resolve and unity, citing Israel as a model. It mentions the crackdown on dissenting political opinions in the name of national security and the pressure on the judiciary in Israel and the US. The article concludes by urging India to learn from global conflicts and challenges and avoid drawing the wrong lessons. It also mentions other topics such as control of temples, the caste-based reservation debate, and the lack of uptake of Kannada medium in engineering courses.

item.title: The World Cup as a farewell tour for top players is well established
item.description: The article discusses how the cricket World Cup often serves as a farewell tour for top players, with many using the occasion to retire from international cricket. It highlights that retirement is no longer seen as the end of a career, with players now having the option to retire from specific formats or continue playing franchise cricket. The article also explores the importance of a proper farewell for long-serving players and mentions examples such as Sachin Tendulkar, who received a memorable send-off, and Steve Waugh, who had a farewell through a whole series. It concludes by noting that some of the finest players of this generation will be playing their final matches in the next few weeks, with the World Cup often serving as a platform for their farewell.

item.title: Left arm spinners, Steve Waugh and India’s near misses twice in a row
item.description: This article discusses the first World Cup match that took place in India 36 years ago. It highlights a dramatic start to the tournament, as Australia defeated India by one run. The author reminisces about the match and the spirit of the Australian team during that time. The article also mentions the importance of singles in one-day cricket, as emphasized by Australia's coach, Bob Simpson. Overall, the article reflects on the past and shares insights about the cricket game.The article discusses the first World Cup match played in India in 1987, where Australia defeated India by one run. The match was significant as it set the tone for Australia's dominance in world cricket for the next few years. The article also mentions the controversy surrounding a disputed six, which was later corrected to a four. Despite India's previous World Cup win and their strong position in the match, they failed to chase down Australia's total of 270. The article highlights the importance of singles in one-day cricket, as emphasized by Australia's coach Bob Simpson. It also mentions a later World Cup match between India and Australia, where India lost by one run again, with Steve Waugh causing the dismissal.

item.title: Readable in one sitting — and other issues
item.description: The article discusses the novella as a literary form and its significance in literature. It highlights the concision, control, and constraint that are characteristic of novellas and mentions some well-known novellas such as Ghachar Ghochar by Vivek Shanbhag and Troubling Love by Elena Ferrante. The article also explores the history of novellas, dating back to the 14th century, and mentions how novellas can serve as an introduction to great writers. Additionally, it discusses the concept of short-form nonfiction and how it relates to the novella genre.

item.title: Test cricket | We are looking at the future, and it isn’t reassuring
item.description: The article discusses the changing landscape of cricket and the potential decline of Test cricket. It highlights the influence of powerful teams like India, Australia, and England, as well as the impact of franchise T20 cricket on the sport. The International Cricket Council (ICC) is seen as being beholden to India, the current superpower in cricket, and is unable to address the decline of Test cricket. The article also mentions South Africa's focus on franchise T20 cricket and their decision to send a second or third-string team to New Zealand for a two-Test series. It raises concerns about the future of cricket, with too much franchise cricket potentially leading to oversaturation and a loss of interest in other formats. The article concludes by suggesting that cricket will undergo significant changes in the future, and that cricket boards need to prioritize the sport's overall well-being rather than solely focusing on financial gains.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — August 25, 2023
item.description: The article clarifies that there was a gain of 2% in the share price of TVS Supply Chain Solutions Limited on its trading debut, rather than a 3% slip as previously reported. Users are also reminded to abide by the community guidelines when commenting.The article clarifies an error in a previous story about the share price of TVS Supply Chain Solutions Limited. The previous story incorrectly stated that the price had slipped 3% on its trading debut, when in fact there was a gain of 2% from the issue price on debut.

item.title: Today’s Cache | AI chatbots and pirated content; Smartphones fly off shelves on Prime Day; TSMC delays chip production in the U.S.
item.description: Authors are urging tech companies to obtain permission from creators before using their copyrighted works to train AI language models. Some writers are planning to take legal action against companies like Google, Meta, and OpenAI, claiming that their copyrighted works were stolen through "shadow libraries" containing pirated content. Amazon's Prime Day saw a high demand for smartphones and TVs, with around five smartphones sold every second. Foldable and 5G-enabled smartphones were particularly popular. Taiwanese chip-maker TSMC has delayed the production of 4nm chips in its Arizona facility by two years due to labor shortages and a lack of skilled workers in the US.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Microsoft’s Activision Blizzard deal nears closure; Musk’s insults boost Zuckerberg’s image; Amazon stresses on low-cost cloud computing
item.description: US District Judge Jacqueline Scott Corley has ruled against blocking Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing a lack of evidence from federal regulators. The ruling comes just before the "break up" fee would have been imposed on Microsoft if the deal fell through. To address regulatory concerns, Microsoft has committed to making Activision Blizzard's Call of Duty accessible on other platforms, including Nintendo's Switch console and Nvidia's cloud gaming service, for at least ten years. Some critics have pointed out that Judge Corley's son works at Microsoft. Meanwhile, Mark Zuckerberg's recent responses to Elon Musk's comments and actions have been seen as more mature, potentially improving Zunckerberg's reputation as the head of Meta. Meta's text-based conversation app Threads has garnered around 100 million sign-ups within a week of its launch, while Twitter users are facing tweet reading limits. Additionally, Amazon's vice president overseeing its applications group, Dilip Kumar, discussed how Amazon Web Services (AWS) aims to lower costs for clients working on generative AI, positioning itself against main competitors Microsoft and Google.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Taliban leader praises Twitter; Meta to label govt-affiliated accounts; Apple opens store on WeChat
item.description: A senior Taliban leader, Anas Haqqani, praised Twitter for its freedom of speech and credibility, contrasting it with Meta's allegedly intolerant policy. Haqqani's tweet came after Meta launched its text-based public conversation app, Threads, which saw significant user sign-ups within a week. Meta plans to label government-affiliated accounts on Threads, and its other platforms, with tags denoting state-controlled media. Additionally, Apple has opened a store on Chinese messaging app WeChat, allowing users to purchase Apple products through the platform. This move aligns with the increasing trend of Chinese consumers turning to social media platforms for shopping.

item.title: Today’s Cache | EU readies for digital euro; Google cuts job at Waze; Meta launches VR subscription
item.description: The European Union (EU) is moving forward with plans to develop a digital version of the euro, despite facing criticism from the public, politicians, and banks. Supporters argue that a digital euro will complement cash and prevent private players and other central banks from filling a potential gap. However, critics raise concerns about payment privacy. In other news, Google-parent Alphabet is cutting jobs at its mapping app Waze as it merges the unit with Google Maps. The move aims to consolidate processes and strengthen Google's mapping and mobile businesses. Additionally, Meta has launched a virtual reality (VR) subscription service for its VR-enabled headsets, offering users access to top gaming titles every month. This announcement comes after Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg expressed his vision for the future of VR.

item.title: No. 3 is a crucial position and Shubman Gill is best suited for it
item.description: This article discusses the different roles and skill sets required for each batting position in cricket. It emphasizes the importance of openers in assessing the pitch and setting the tone for the innings. The middle order is described as the team's engine room, responsible for building on good starts or compensating for poor ones. The No. 3 position is highlighted as crucial, linking the top and middle order and often occupied by the best batter in the side. The article suggests grooming Shubman Gill as India's No. 3, with Rohit Sharma and Yeshaswi Jaiswal opening. It also mentions the importance of imagination and creativity in team selection. The article concludes by mentioning the positional fluidity in modern Test cricket and how batters prefer to stick to their most comfortable and productive positions.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Baidu’s AI claims; Google’s Android antitrust woes; Qualcomm launches new 5G SoC
item.description: Chinese company Baidu claims that its AI chatbot, the Ernie AI model, has surpassed OpenAI's ChatGPT in several key metrics. This comes as more Chinese companies, including Alibaba and Tencent, announce their own rival AI products. Google has also requested that the Supreme Court of India dismiss antitrust directives against it for alleged abuse of the Android market. Meanwhile, Qualcomm has announced the Snapdragon 4 Gen 2 SOC processor for entry-level smartphones, which is expected to bring down the price of 5G phones and improve battery life.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Chatbots and mental health; Google infringed patents; Tech companies allege unfair cloud practices
item.description: The use of mental health chatbots powered by AI is increasing, but it comes with both benefits and risks. While some counselors believe that chatbots can simulate empathy, a study found that bots' answers were rated higher for quality and empathy compared to physicians. However, privacy and protection remain concerns, as chatbot apps could potentially share personal information with third parties. In other news, Google has been ordered to pay $15.1 million for infringing on two patents related to audio software. The company plans to appeal the verdict. Additionally, technology trade groups, including Google, have complained to the Federal Trade Commission about alleged unfair practices in the cloud market, accusing vendors of using anti-competitive practices to prevent customers from switching providers.

item.title: Today’s Cache | E.U. regulators target Google’s ad-tech business; FTC looks to block Microsoft-Activision deal; Centre denies CoWIN data breach
item.description: European Union antitrust regulators are considering ordering Google to sell a part of its advertising technology business in an effort to reduce the tech giant's dominance in digital ads. Google currently holds a 28% market share of global ad revenue and has faced increasing scrutiny over its dominance in online advertising. The US Federal Trade Commission has also sought to block Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns about potential changes in the company and competition in the cloud gaming market. In India, the Ministry of Health has denied reports of a data breach of COVID vaccination beneficiaries, stating that the claims are baseless and mischievous. The Indian Computer Emergency Response Team has been asked to investigate the issue.

item.title: IPL to WTC | Fitness and adaptability are the keys; how about the Dhoni Cup?
item.description: The article discusses how modern cricketers are adaptable and can easily switch between formats and locations without their performance suffering. It mentions that most international series are now played without any first-class matches in the build-up, unlike in the past. The article also highlights how playing in the Indian Premier League (IPL) can serve as good preparation for test cricket, as seen in the cases of Joe Root and Jonny Bairstow. It suggests that batters may find it easier to adjust, while bowlers may need to work harder. The article concludes by discussing the significance of the IPL and the potential future role of players like Mahendra Singh Dhoni and Shubman Gill.

item.title: Kohli and Root — two contemporary greats and their different approaches
item.description: The article discusses the contrasting approaches of cricketers Joe Root and Virat Kohli in T20 cricket. While Kohli stays true to his traditional techniques and emphasizes playing his own game, Root is reinventing himself as a T20 player and exploring new shots. The article raises the question of whether there can be a distinction between "highbrow" and "lowbrow" in sports, specifically referring to test cricket and T20 cricket. It also highlights the importance of playing to one's strengths and compensating for weaknesses in order to succeed. Root's determination to play in the T20 World Cup is mentioned, suggesting that he is willing to adapt and not necessarily prioritize elegance in his batting style.

item.title: Bhujang Shetty: The eye doctor with a vision
item.description: The article pays tribute to Dr Bhujang Shetty, a renowned ophthalmologist who recently passed away. The author recalls their time together in school, where Bhujang was known for his kindness and leadership. Despite their age difference, Bhujang always made an effort to greet the author and was friendly to everyone. The author reflects on Bhujang's compassion and calmness, qualities that made him an excellent doctor. Bhujang was also a talented athlete and hard worker. The author reconnects with Bhujang later in life and admires his dedication to eye donation and building the Dr Rajkumar Eye Bank. Bhujang's legacy as a friend and a good man is remembered fondly by those who knew him.

item.title: India deserve the money, but the ICC needs to work out a better system
item.description: The article discusses the financial dynamics within the International Cricket Council (ICC) and how money has become the basis of power within the organization. In 2014, England, Australia, and India proposed a revenue-sharing model that favored them over other countries. This model has been proposed again for the cycle of 2024-2027, where India would take home the largest portion of the surplus revenue. The article argues that while self-interest is understandable, the ICC should prioritize the growth of the game and ensure that the money is used for the development of cricket. Currently, the countries that need the funding the most are receiving the least amount.

item.title: Cricket shouldn’t float on barrels of oil at a time of climate crisis
item.description: The article discusses the challenges faced by test cricket and the sport of cricket as a whole. It highlights the issue of national boards losing control of players to self-interested few and the increasing influence of Indian franchises. The article also mentions two external threats to the sport – climate change and Saudi Arabia's sportswashing ambitions. It highlights the impact of climate change on cricket, particularly in low-lying areas, and emphasizes the importance of considering sponsors' contributions to the climate crisis. The article raises concerns about Saudi Arabia's involvement in cricket and suggests that the game's integrity should not be compromised for financial gain. It concludes by suggesting that the changing landscape of cricket, both internally and externally, poses a significant challenge to the sport.

item.title: Mirror, mirror, is that me?
item.description: The article discusses the ability of various animals, including humans, to recognize themselves in a mirror. It explains that the "Mirror test" is often used to determine self-recognition, where a mark is placed on the subject's face and their reaction is observed. The article mentions that even young children show signs of self-recognition around 18 months of age. It then introduces a study conducted on bluestreak cleaner wrasse fish, which also showed signs of self-recognition. The fish would attack the mirror image at first but eventually recognized itself and only showed aggression towards images of strangers. The article concludes by questioning whether self-recognition can be considered self-awareness and mentions that human children typically develop self-recognition around the same age as the fish in the study.

item.title: Column | Where are we at, three years after India locked down for COVID-19?
item.description: The article reflects on the three-year anniversary of the COVID-19 lockdown in India and explores how people's lives have changed during this time. It discusses personal experiences, such as moving out of cities, losing jobs, finding love, and going through gender transitions. The author reflects on the feeling of the lockdown itself, describing it as a time when established rules were rendered irrelevant and people had to find new ways of doing everyday things. The article also highlights how families came together during this period, focusing on unity against the common enemy of the pandemic. It mentions the emergence of new traditions, such as Zoom calls. Additionally, the article discusses the current trend of "revenge" activities, such as travel and weddings, as people try to make up for what they feel they missed during the lockdown. However, it suggests that people may have lost the ability to appreciate the small joys of life and have become greedy and dissatisfied.

item.title: World Test Championship final — no room for experimentation
item.description: The article discusses the upcoming World Test Championship final between India and Australia. It highlights the challenges India will face without key players and the need for a strong combination of talent, experience, and form. The article also mentions the possibility of using two spinners or one in away tests and the importance of making strategic selections. It further discusses the batting slots and the performance of players like Shubman Gill and Axar Patel. The article acknowledges Australia's strong bowling and considers them as slim favorites for the final. Additionally, it reflects on the pitch conditions in Ahmedabad and the impact on batting and bowling performances. The article concludes by mentioning the upcoming one-day series and the importance of respectful and English comments in response to the article.

item.title: The evil effects of deforestation
item.description: The article discusses the impact of deforestation on the environment and human health. It highlights that 420 million hectares of forests have been lost since 1990 to make way for agriculture, industry, and biofuels. This deforestation contributes to global warming, as trees absorb carbon dioxide. The article also mentions that deforestation leads to an increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the spread of diseases like malaria and dengue. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of saving not only trees but also soil and water. The article provides examples of deforestation in India, including the destruction of forests in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, as well as in the states of Jammu and Kashmir, Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, and Goa. It concludes by urging readers to protest against deforestation.

item.title: Cricket selection | Putting the human back in the machine
item.description: This article discusses the role of selectors in cricket and the importance of team selection. It highlights the recent controversy surrounding India's selectors and the dilemma they face in choosing between in-form Shubman Gill and out-of-form KL Rahul. The article introduces the book "Making Decisions: Putting the Human Back in the Machine" by former England selector Ed Smith, which emphasizes the need for selectors to consider the human aspect and rely on their instincts in addition to data. The author argues that selectors should not always stick to conventional choices and should be willing to take risks in selecting players based on their potential rather than just their performance. The article concludes by discussing the importance of disruptive and imaginative thinking in selection meetings and the need to eliminate bureaucratic inertia.

item.title: A peer, a pot and a ‘prescription’
item.description: Hmm, I'm sorry, but I can only provide information and support related to Chatbase. item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — February 16, 2023
item.description: The article addresses a correction that needs to be made to an opinion piece titled "Constitutional Oath is not a mere formality." The correction states that the article cited the wrong section, Article 173, and it should be corrected to Article 191. The article also mentions that comments should be in English, in full sentences, and follow community guidelines. The Hindu has migrated to a new commenting platform. Registered users can continue to engage with articles, and older comments can be accessed through their accounts on Vuukle.

item.title: An India-Australia series is about cricket, there’s no baggage
item.description: The article discusses the unique relationship between India and Australia in cricket. Unlike series against other countries, the focus in India-Australia cricket is purely on the sport and not influenced by politics, religion, or culture. The article highlights the historical connections between the two countries, such as Indian soldiers fighting alongside Australians in World War I and the first Australian tour of India organized by Frank Tarrant in 1935-36. The article also mentions the contributions of Australians in writing books on Indian cricket and the popularity of Australian teams as tourists in India. Despite these connections, the competition between India and Australia remains intense. The article concludes by stating that the upcoming four-test series between the two countries is highly anticipated and could see new players like Shubman Gill, Cameron Green, Trevor Head, and Kuldeep Yadav making their mark in the sport.

item.title: Pollticks: Jobs get highest mention in last Budget before elections
item.description: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman presented India's fifth union budget, focusing on boosting domestic consumption and private investments. The budget aimed to create a positive sentiment among specific voter segments ahead of the 2024 Lok Sabha elections. Some key highlights include raising the tax-free limit for the salaried middle class and increasing the cap on non-government employees' retirement benefits. The budget also introduced new socio-economic development schemes for vulnerable tribal groups and artisans from weaker sections. Measures were announced to support micro, small, and medium enterprises, and the budget emphasized the importance of job creation, particularly for the youth. The plan to ramp up infrastructure expenditure and revive private investments will depend on states and industry taking bold steps during a challenging economic environment. The government also introduced measures to assist senior citizens and women in saving and investment. Overall, the budget aims to achieve inclusive development and pave the way for India's centenary of independence in 2047.

item.title: Budget 2023 | Push to achieve net zero emissions: P.B. Balaji
item.description: The article discusses the Union Budget 2023 and highlights its positive aspects. It mentions that the budget aims to balance economic growth with fiscal prudence and puts money in the hands of consumers to drive domestic consumption. The budget also focuses on turbo-charging investments, with a significant increase in capex outlay and continued interest-free loans to state governments. It emphasizes the importance of accelerating the green transition, with allocations for energy transition and a low-carbon economy. The budget also includes measures to support the auto industry and reduce carbon emissions. Overall, the article views the budget as confident, balanced, and likely to spur consumption, attract investments, and build global confidence in India's sustainable growth story.

item.title: Budget 2023, target 2047: Ashok Hinduja
item.description: The article summarizes the key highlights of India's budget for 2023. The budget focuses on green energy transition, with an allocation of ₹35,000 crores for achieving energy security and net zero objectives. Infrastructure and investment have also been prioritized, with a 33% increase in capital expenditure outlay and plans for the development of 50 new airports. The agriculture sector is set to receive increased support, including an 11% hike in agriculture credit target and the establishment of an agriculture accelerator fund. The budget also includes measures to promote fintech and digital payments, aiming to create a digital economy for the entire nation.

item.title: Budget 2023 | Brilliant balancing act between growth, fiscal consolidation: Sanjiv Bajaj
item.description: This article discusses the Union Budget proposals for fiscal year 2023 in India. The author describes it as a brilliant balancing act that focuses on fiscal consolidation and high growth. The budget emphasizes capital expenditure-led growth, with a 33% increase in gross fixed capital formation expected, which will boost economic productivity and unlock India's growth potential. The budget also aims to encourage private investments through public capex and infrastructure push, ease of doing business, green growth interventions, and support for agri startups. Inclusion and targeted support are a strong theme, with a focus on agriculture, skill development, and schemes for women, elderly, and youth. The budget also prioritizes employment and employability, aiming to enhance the income and consumption demand in the economy. Fiscal consolidation is seen as imperative for macro-economic stability and investor confidence. The budget also emphasizes cooperative federalism and reform push. Overall, the article concludes that the budget is growth-oriented and aims to strengthen the foundations of the Indian economy.

item.title: Budget 2023 | On the right course: A growth-oriented Budget: Keki Mistry
item.description: In this article, Keki Mistry, the Vice-Chairman and CEO of HDFC Ltd, praises the Indian government's efforts in the recent Union Budget to boost economic growth, employment, savings, and investments. Mistry commends the government for keeping the fiscal deficit in line with the budget estimates and reducing it in the coming years. The government's measures to increase the tax base, enhance transparency, and improve ease of doing business are seen as positive steps. Mistry also highlights the government's focus on the salaried class, with rationalized income taxes aimed at promoting savings and consumption. The allocation of funds for affordable housing and urban infrastructure development is viewed as a positive move. The author sees the increased capital expenditure as a strong signal that India is ready to absorb investment and achieve sustained economic growth. Overall, Mistry considers this budget as excellent and believes it will help India achieve its goal of becoming a $5 trillion economy by 2025.

item.title: Budget 2023 | Building resilience and boosting growth: Chandrajit Banerjee
item.description: The article discusses the first budget of India's Amrit Kaal (Golden Age), which focuses on bolstering near-term and medium-term economic growth. The budget emphasizes inclusive development, green growth, urban upgradation, strengthening the financial sector, and digital infrastructure. It aims to boost consumption and investment through increased capital spending and interest-free loans for state capital expenditure. The budget also supports consumption through the rationalization of personal tax rates. The rise in capital spending is expected to be supported by a reduction in subsidies and growth in gross tax revenue. The budget also prioritizes boosting the rural economy and improving the ease of doing business. Overall, the budget maintains fiscal discipline while promoting growth and lays the foundation for economic ascent in the coming years.

item.title: Budget 2023 | Choosing the path of prudence and continuity: T.T. Srinivasaraghavan
item.description: In this article, T.T. Srinivasaraghavan praises the Indian Finance Minister's budget for its focus on key areas such as infrastructure, agriculture, digitization, and green initiatives. The author commends the government's commitment to building world-class infrastructure and highlights the importance of supporting the MSME sector. The article also mentions the attention-grabbing direct tax proposals, which signal a shift away from exemptions. The author concludes by stating that despite the annual budget circus, this budget is the best in the finance minister's tenure.

item.title: Those fascinating hornbills
item.description: The article discusses the importance of hornbills in India and their role in seed dispersal. Hornbills are large birds with heavy beaks and are found in various regions of India. They prefer tall trees for nesting and play a vital role in dispersing the seeds of rainforest trees. However, their populations have been declining due to illegal logging and hunting. The article also mentions that forest plantations are not as suitable for hornbill populations as natural-growth rainforests. Overall, the article highlights the ecological significance of hornbills and the need for their conservation.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Battery from nuclear waste to power space missions
item.description: Scientists at the European Space Agency (ESA) are developing batteries made of Americium, a nuclear waste material, to power space missions. The technology is expected to be developed by the end of the decade and will be used for missions in areas where solar power is limited, such as the dark side of the Moon or far-off regions of the Solar System. The batteries will be encapsulated in layers to ensure safety, and Americium will be extracted from reprocessed nuclear fuel to make fuel pellets for the batteries. Americium is cheaper, more abundant, and has a longer half-life compared to the currently used plutonium-238 batteries. The ESA has approved a funding of $30 million for the battery system, and plans to launch Americium-based power sources in moon missions in the early 2030s. The technology is also of interest to NASA for its Artemis program.

item.title: Today’s Cache | ChatGPT opens a new search paradigm
item.description: OpenAI has introduced its large language model (LLM) ChatGPT, which allows users to interact with it using natural language. The chatbot not only answers questions but also corrects codes in computer programs. While there are limitations to the chatbot's responses, it has the potential to fundamentally change the way we search the web. OpenAI's chatbot is built on GPT 3.5 architecture and is powered by Microsoft's cloud. The chatbot could be monetized in the future, and there may be a need for a watermark solution to prevent misuse of its capabilities.

item.title: Political Line | Is this Rahul Gandhi’s ‘Quitting Politics’ yatra?
item.description: The article discusses Congress leader Rahul Gandhi's Bharat Jodo Yatra and speculates on his intentions and motivations behind it. The author suggests that the yatra is not about rebranding himself politically or reviving the Congress party, but rather a personal transformation for Gandhi from a career politician to a civil society activist. The article also briefly mentions the controversy surrounding the terms "Adivasi" and "Vanvasi" and caste-based discrimination in Tamil Nadu.The article discusses Congress leader Rahul Gandhi's Bharat Jodo Yatra and speculates on his intentions and motivations behind it. The author suggests that the yatra is not about rebranding himself politically or reviving the Congress party, but rather a personal transformation for Gandhi from a career politician to a civil society activist. The article also briefly mentions the controversy surrounding the terms "Adivasi" and "Vanvasi" and caste-based discrimination in Tamil Nadu.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — January 27, 2022
item.description: The article corrects an error in a previous report regarding the year of Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's last visit to India. It should have been 2022, not 2021.The article corrects an error in a previous report regarding the year of Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's last visit to India. It should have been 2022, not 2021.The article corrects an error in a previous report regarding the year of Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's last visit to India. It should have been 2022, not 2021.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — January 19, 2023
item.description: The article is a correction and clarification notice regarding a previous report titled "In a landmark shift, China's population declines in 2022." A reader pointed out an error in the accompanying graph, where the population marks of India and South Africa were incorrectly placed on the same line. The correction states that India's mark should be on the line above. The article also mentions that comments on the platform should be in English, in full sentences, and should adhere to community guidelines. The Hindu has migrated to a new commenting platform, and registered users can continue to engage with articles.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — January 18, 2023
item.description: The article discusses a correction made to an Op-Ed page article titled "Ground Zero." The correction states that the altitude of Joshimath was incorrectly mentioned as 6,000 meters above sea level, when it should have been 6,000 feet.The article discusses a correction made to an Op-Ed page article titled "Ground Zero." The correction states that the altitude of Joshimath was incorrectly mentioned as 6,000 meters above sea level, when it should have been 6,000 feet.The article discusses a correction made to an Op-Ed page article titled "Ground Zero." The correction states that the altitude of Joshimath was incorrectly mentioned as 6,000 meters above sea level, when it should have been 6,000 feet.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — January 17, 2022
item.description: The article titled "Cong. govt. keeps poll promise, decides to restore old pension scheme in H.P." (January 14, 2023) made an error in stating a 3% increase in GST on diesel. The correct information is that there will be an increase in the Value Added Tax on diesel by ₹3 per litre.The article titled "Cong. govt. keeps poll promise, decides to restore old pension scheme in H.P." (January 14, 2023) made an error in stating a 3% increase in GST on diesel. The correct information is that there will be an increase in the Value Added Tax on diesel by ₹3 per litre.

item.title: Stokes and the modern age: what next in this brave new world?
item.description: In this article, the author praises Ben Stokes as the cricketer of the year and credits him for bringing excitement back into test cricket. They question if other countries will adopt England's strategy of quick scoring and positive cricket to attract larger crowds. They also inquire about the sustainability of England's style of play and if it guarantees consistent success. The author mentions that Steve Smith and David Warner are intrigued by England's approach. They also discuss the concept of "bazball," named after coach Brendon McCullum, and how England's success has shown that a system or philosophy can be worked out first before selecting players. The article emphasizes the impact of Stokes' contributions on and off the field, highlighting his creative field placements and infusing the team with energy and spirit. The author acknowledges that test cricket needs help against T20 tournaments and expresses curiosity about India's approach in this changing landscape. The article concludes by stating that this will be an interesting year for test cricket, and India could demonstrate alternative ways to win a match.

item.title: Our cucumbers, melons and gourds
item.description: This article discusses the cucurbitaceae family of plants, which includes cucumbers, watermelons, melons, pumpkins, and squashes. Cucurbits have been important components of food economies for thousands of years and are grown in various regions of the world. Cucumbers are indigenous to India and wild relatives of cucumber are found growing in the foothills of the Himalayas. The article also mentions the domestication of melons in Africa and India, with variations in size, taste, and bitterness. Bitter gourds, another member of the cucurbitaceae family, differ in taste and appearance in various regions, such as Thailand and India. Cucurbits are not only dietary mainstays but also have medicinal value. They are low in calories and high in water content, making them a healthy food choice. Additionally, cucurbits have other interesting uses, such as the loofah or sponge gourd being used as a sponge in skincare and dried bottle gourds being used as resonators in musical instruments.

item.title: Satire | Since the Bharat Jodo Yatra began, India has lost about 8.9 lakh kg, of which 4.9 lakh kg belong to the BJP and 2.2 lakh kg to the Congress
item.description: This article tells the story of K. Thiruvengadasivasamy, or KTS, who was the deputy vice chancellor-cum-cook at a fake university in California. When the author was invited to speak at the university, KTS offered financial incentives for the author to come to the university. However, the author suggested that the university open a campus in India instead, which led to a signing of an agreement between the university and the government of Uttar Pradesh. Unfortunately, it was later discovered that the university was fake, leaving KTS in a difficult situation. KTS then joined the Bharat Jodo Yatra (BJY), an initiative by the Congress party to promote fitness in India. Through participating in the yatra, KTS lost 55kg and shared that India as a whole has collectively shed a significant amount of weight through the yatra. The author concludes the article by emphasizing the inspiring nature of political leaders promoting fitness and encourages others to walk more in 2023.

item.title: Making tough calls to get it right matters more now than ever before
item.description: This article discusses the current state of Indian cricket, particularly focusing on the team's performance and potential changes in the future. The author highlights the team's recent 2-0 series win but also points out weaknesses and the need for improvement, particularly in their batting against spin. The article emphasizes the importance of selection based on performance rather than sentiment, suggesting that some senior players may need to be dropped if necessary. The article also mentions the upcoming World Test Championship and the need for India to win matches against Australia to secure a spot in the final. The 50-over World Cup is also mentioned as a future concern. Overall, the article suggests that India must address their weaknesses and make strategic decisions to improve their performance in cricket.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — December 19, 2022
item.description: The article discusses a correction made to a previous story titled "Curbing Air Pollution in India Needs Efforts Across South Asia: WB Report." The correction states that the PM2.5 figures mentioned in the story were mistakenly given in grams per cubic meter instead of micrograms per cubic meter. The article also mentions that comments on the platform must be in English, in full sentences, and abide by the community guidelines. Additionally, it informs readers that the commenting platform has been migrated to a new system but registered users can still engage with the articles.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Lensa AI is greenroom app that uses community tools as its own
item.description: The article discusses the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) applications such as OpenAI's chatbot, GPT-3.5, and Prisma Labs' Lensa AI. GPT-3.5 is a language model that can answer text questions and fix programming codes. It is trained on a variety of data sources such as social media posts, Wikipedia, and news articles. On the other hand, Lensa AI is an app that uses a machine learning model to create artistic portrait images based on selfie photographs. However, the app has faced criticism for using digital images scraped from the web without giving credit or payment to the original artists. Despite these concerns, Lensa AI has gained popularity and achieved the top spot in Apple's app store. The app offers advanced editing features but also raises privacy concerns as it collects user data and grants the app rights to user content.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Elon Musk picks a quarrel with Tim Cook
item.description: Elon Musk's recent quarrel with Apple is causing trouble for his platform, Twitter. Musk has been making changes on Twitter since purchasing the platform, including laying off half the staff, which led to voluntary resignations and advertisers leaving. In an attempt to keep the platform active, Musk reinstated former President Donald Trump's account and launched a paid blue verification tick mark. However, the launch did not go smoothly, and the service had to be relaunched. It is speculated that Apple's 30% app tax played a role in delaying the relaunch, as Musk would have to pay a third of his earnings from selling blue tick marks to Apple. Musk publicly criticized Apple's app store in-app purchase policy, calling it a "hidden 30% tax on the internet." He also claimed that Apple has stopped advertising on Twitter and threatened to withhold the platform from its app store, though Apple has not publicly responded.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Twitter’s anti-propaganda team grapples with Chinese spam accounts on lockdown protests
item.description: China is experiencing anti-lockdown protests as citizens oppose the country's zero-covid policy. According to a report by Washington Post, China's state-backed accounts are spamming hashtags on Twitter, including hashtags related to protests. Twitter staff are trying to fight back against this stream of spam, particularly targeting city names such as Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Zhengzhou, and Lanzhou. The protests have been fueled by issues such as confusion surrounding hiring, mass quarantines, worker bonuses, and lockdowns as part of China's zero-tolerance approach to COVID-19. Some protestors have been sharing videos online to raise awareness about their situation. It is noted that Twitter's staff has significantly decreased in number following mass layoffs and resignations after Elon Musk took over the platform. Activists and researchers have expressed concerns about the impact this reduced manpower may have on handling spam and ensuring access to vital information during anti-regime protests.

item.title: Today’s Cache | How Amazon uses feedback from video reviewers to train algorithms?
item.description: Amazon is reportedly using offshore workers in India and Costa Rica to review camera footage from its warehouses in order to train its monitoring algorithms. These workers provide feedback on the footage, which is used to improve Amazon's AI camera system. The workers are paid low salaries and face physical problems and stringent targets. Amazon has defended its practices, stating that the majority of its team is not represented by the report's allegations.Amazon is reportedly using offshore workers in India and Costa Rica to review camera footage from its warehouses. The feedback from these video reviewers is used to train the company's AI camera system that monitors the stowing process in the warehouses. Reviewers are paid low wages and are expected to watch thousands of videos per day, leading to physical problems and high-stress targets. Amazon claims that its system is 95% accurate and that reviewers are encouraged to take breaks. The report is based on interviews with current and former Amazon employees.

item.title: Today’s Cache | JioCinema chokes in its maiden stream of FIFA World Cup 2022
item.description: The article discusses the frustration of Indian football fans with the JioCinema app, which is the only way to watch the FIFA World Cup in India for free. Users complained about buffering issues and missed goals during live streaming. The article explains that streaming involves a series of steps including compression, encoding, segmentation, and distribution through a content distribution network (CDN). If the CDN is not functioning properly, it can cause streaming issues. If the app does not fix its CDN issue, users may switch to traditional set-top boxes to watch the rest of the World Cup.

item.title: What’s Musk got to do with it?
item.description: The article discusses the recent actions of Kanye West and Elon Musk on social media and how their behavior was influenced by the validation and attention they received. It highlights the consequences of their actions, such as damaging their reputations and impacting others' livelihoods. The article also reflects on the shift from glorifying disruption to recognizing its potentially devastating effects. Overall, it suggests that these disruptions and upheavals are becoming more commonplace in our technology-driven world.The article discusses the recent behaviors of Kanye West and Elon Musk on social media, highlighting their spirals fueled by social media validation. It emphasizes how being rich and famous can create a sense of entitlement that leads to a cycle of pushing boundaries and seeking validation, which eventually goes too far. The author suggests that celebrities are driven by the fear of being unloved and therefore engage in attention-seeking behaviors. The article also criticizes Musk's actions in taking over Twitter and the potential negative impact on the platform's content moderation and whistleblowers. It concludes by reflecting on how the world has become a playground for the rich, where disruption has been glorified but may not always be beneficial in the long run.

item.title: Today’s Cache | Did Twitter’s ex-boss Parag Agrawal fail tweeps?
item.description: Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter in a $44 billion deal has resulted in increased wealth for the platform's former owners and bosses. However, the article highlights that stakeholders, including employees, were not given enough consideration during the deal-making process. The lack of a deal to benefit employees is criticized, particularly noting that allocating a small percentage of the monetary gains to employee protection could have provided financial support for those who were let go after the deal's closing. The article emphasizes the importance of considering stakeholders and delivering long-term value to customers, employees, and communities.

item.title: Meta Quest Pro VR users need almost five hours to read its privacy policy: report
item.description: Mozilla researchers have discovered that it would take hours to read through the privacy policy for Meta's new Quest Pro VR headset. In Mozilla's 'Privacy Not Included' guide, it was noted that big tech companies like Meta, Verizon, and Amazon release lengthy privacy policies for their devices, some of which run for tens of thousands of words. The researchers estimated that it would take around four hours and fifty minutes to read all the privacy documents associated with the Meta Quest Pro. Mozilla suggested that the overwhelming volume of documents could be used to pressure users into quickly agreeing to the terms, potentially allowing their data to be collected and sold to external parties.

item.title: In sport, you often learn more from a defeat than from a victory
item.description: This article discusses the benefits of early defeat in a World Cup tournament. It suggests that losing early can rid a team of complacency, highlight weaknesses, motivate players, and improve team selection. The article mentions that Australia, despite starting with two defeats, now looks like one of the favorites in the tournament. On the other hand, England, the reigning champions, are currently at the bottom of the table, putting their qualification for the 2025 Champions Trophy in jeopardy. India, on the other hand, has won all their matches convincingly and is considered a strong candidate to go through undefeated. The article emphasizes that successful teams learn from defeat and disappointment, and that there are lessons to be learned from both victory and defeat. It also warns against the temptation to hold onto a once-victorious team, as England is currently facing, and suggests that India may face similar problems in the future if they don't learn from England's mistakes. The article concludes by stating that there are lessons to be learned from both defeat and victory, but it is important to learn the right ones.

item.title: Political Line | Clarity of the extremist; disorientation of the liberal
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the issue of criticizing religions and the rise of religious extremism. It highlights that extremists of all religions claim that their views represent the essence of their religion and argue that the actions of extremists from other religions reveal the true character of those religions. The article also mentions the efforts by governments in France, Germany, and the US to regulate or contain views critical of Israel or supporting Palestinians, which is seen as a threat to freedom of expression and individual liberty. The author points out the complexity faced by liberals in navigating these issues, while extremists find clarity in their beliefs. The article concludes by mentioning the promotion of regional pride in Karnataka and the legal challenges faced by two Indian states regarding the conduct of their Governors.

item.title: Corrections and Clarifications — November 7, 2023
item.description: The article is a corrections and clarifications notice regarding two previous articles published. The first correction states that Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck is Bhutan's fifth king, not the fourth. The second correction specifies the correct scores in the tennis match between Dimitrov and Tsitsipas at the Paris Masters. The article also mentions that comments on the platform must be in English, in full sentences, and should not be abusive or personal.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article reports on two corrections and clarifications made in recent news reports. The first correction states that Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck is the fifth king of Bhutan, not the fourth. The second correction pertains to a sports story where Grigor Dimitrov's scores were published incorrectly. The correct scores should have been 6-3, 6-7(1), 7-6(3). The article also mentions that comments on the platform should be in English, in full sentences, and should adhere to community guidelines.

item.title: Column | Longing and a side of tehar
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article tells the story of a gathering of women in a Kashmiri village who come together to share their longings and find solace in each other's company. The author, who is visiting her aunt Phuphee, witnesses this gathering and learns about the deep bond and understanding that exists among the women. They gather at Phuphee's house unannounced and spend the day talking, reciting poetry, and comforting each other. They eat tehar (turmeric rice), drink kehwa (tea), and massage mustard oil into each other's hair as a way to alleviate the burdens of their hearts. The author realizes that these gatherings serve as a form of healing and sisterhood, providing an outlet for the unexpressed longings that women carry.

item.title: Political Line | The stories that make a nation
item.description: The article discusses the controversy surrounding the installation of a golden sceptre, called sengol, in India's new Parliament building. The opposition parties boycotted the inauguration, and The Hindu editorial criticized the move as an attempt to reimagine India's founding principles. The BJP has embellished the event, linking it to the transfer of power from British rule to Congress. However, this claim lacks historical basis. The article also highlights the BJP's attempt to undermine Dravidian politics in Tamil Nadu by appropriating a Saivite sect. The author suggests that the official narrative will overshadow the facts over time. Additionally, the article covers other political topics such as Assam's changing linguistic landscape, north-south divide in politics, criticism of a mural in Parliament, delimitation of Lok Sabha seats, and the retention of sedition laws.

item.title: Column | Is it time to shut up?
item.description: The article discusses the culture of commenting and expressing opinions on social media platforms. The author reflects on their own experiences and how the internet has evolved over time. They mention a video clip featuring the Dalai Lama, which sparked controversy, and express their uncertainty about whether to comment on it. The author also talks about the rise of online arguments and the tendency for people to become rooted in their opinions. They highlight the complexity of issues and the importance of understanding that things are not always black and white. The article mentions a book by Jon Ronson called "So You've Been Publicly Shamed," which explores the impact of social media shaming. The author admits to having fewer opinions and realizing their lack of knowledge on various topics. They caution against engaging in mindless online outrage and suggest taking a moment to reflect before commenting.

item.title: Political Line | Savarkar vs Gandhi; NAMO vs RAGA
item.description: The article discusses the differing approaches of Rahul Gandhi and Narendra Modi, two key figures in Indian politics. Gandhi's statement on V.D. Savarkar's apology letter caused controversy within his own party alliance, while Modi emphasized the teachings of Buddha to address global challenges. The article also explores how Hindutva organizations have selectively embraced and ignored aspects of Savarkar's philosophy. It mentions the Congress party's struggle to maintain ideological purity and its late recognition of leaders like Ambedkar and Patel. The article concludes by highlighting the importance of ethical politics in the present and the ongoing debate on caste representation in positions of power.

item.title: Column | Chicken broth and some pluck
item.description: The article tells the story of Phuphee, a woman who is determined to ensure education for girls in her village. She discovers that the girls' school is facing issues due to harassment from security personnel stationed nearby. Phuphee confronts the authorities and offers them a bowl of tchatte rass, a traditional broth, as a gesture of courage. Eventually, the bunker is moved, and the school is saved. Phuphee emphasizes the importance of education, stating that it teaches critical thinking and reduces dependence on others. The article concludes with Phuphee urging a young girl to focus on her studies and not rely on men to explain things to her.

item.title: Column | An accidental cruelty
item.description: The article tells the story of a woman named Masarat who suffered repeated miscarriages and faced social stigma in her village. The author, reflecting on her own experience of miscarriage, recalls how Masarat's ordeal affected her. One day, Masarat had a miscarriage and refused to go to the hospital. Instead, she was brought to Phuphee's house, where Phuphee took care of her. When Masarat's mother believed her daughter had died, Phuphee explained that she wanted her to understand the pain of loss. Despite questioning her actions, Phuphee believed it was easier to bear the mother's grief than to face Masarat's death. The article highlights the complexities of healing others and the personal sacrifices involved.

item.title: Political Line | Digital mohalla sabhas, and international relations
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the democratization of diplomacy and the increasing influence of public opinion on strategic decision-making in India and other democracies. It highlights the rise of populism and its impact on governance, emphasizing the contradictory calls for centralization and decentralization in governance prescriptions. In India, populism aligns with the deep state, military, and security apparatus, advocating for India to become a superpower and endorsing military spending and aggression. On the other hand, Western populism primarily opposes the national security apparatus and criticizes unending wars conducted by elite strategists. The article also mentions the challenges faced by strategists in dealing with assertive public opinion on international relations. It references Prime Minister Narendra Modi's attempts to balance India's positions in conflicts, despite pressure from his supporters who demand unwavering support for Israel. The article concludes by discussing the questioning of traditional approaches to conflicts by the public and the power of people's movements in shaping political outcomes.

item.title: Political Line | Brownwashing conservative politics in the U.S. and the U.K.
item.description: The article discusses the emergence of Vivek Ramaswamy and Suella Braverman as prominent leaders in conservative politics in the United States and the United Kingdom, respectively. Despite their Indian origins and brown skin, they have become advocates for national identity and western values. Ramaswamy focuses on the commonalities between Hinduism and Christianity, criticizes American capitalism, and supports border control and restricted membership. Similarly, Braverman emphasizes the challenges of uncontrolled migration and multiculturalism, advocating for integration and western identity. The article suggests that the alliance between conservative causes and brown and white populations may shape the future of western identity. It also briefly mentions other news stories, such as the decision of the Mizoram government regarding collecting data from Myanmar refugees and the efforts to preserve a language in West Bengal.

item.title: Column | Beauty and the beasts
item.description: The article tells a story about Phuphee, a wise woman who helps her neighbor Bashir with his troubled cows. Phuphee suggests two solutions: slaughtering the cows or performing a ritual involving reading verses from the Quran. However, it is later revealed that Phuphee didn't actually curse the cows but instead advised Bashir's wife to milk them when he sleeps and let them loose, making him think they were cursed. The article highlights the importance of offering help that empowers individuals to make their own decisions rather than controlling or manipulating them. Phuphee's wisdom is compared to her cooking, appearing simple but requiring a lifetime of mastery.

item.title: Political Line | Reversing democracy for stability
item.description: The article discusses the concept of 'one nation, one election' proposed by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in India. The idea is to have simultaneous polling for Parliament, State Assemblies, and local bodies every five years. Proponents argue that this approach would reduce election expenses, minimize disruptions to government officials and development work, and prevent hung Assemblies and unstable governments. However, critics argue that this proposal restricts the fundamental freedom of expression in a democracy, as voting is a crucial aspect of democratic rights. They also highlight the diversity of India and the importance of accommodating multiple parties and opinions. Additionally, the article touches on the ongoing ethnic conflict between the Kuki and Meitei communities in Manipur and the challenges faced by smaller tribes in being identified as either Kuki or Naga. The author warns that the 'one nation, one election' concept may jeopardize the expansion and deepening of Indian democracy.

item.title: Column | It’s OK to err, says Phuphee
item.description: The article recounts a personal experience of the author when they were slapped by a teacher for accidentally breaking a flower vase in the classroom. The author reflects on how this form of discipline was normal during their childhood, and how it shaped their behavior and mindset. They highlight the contrasting approach of their relative, Phuphee, who never used physical punishment or scolding. Phuphee believed in allowing children to make mistakes and learn from them, fostering courage and resilience. The author realizes the impact of Phuphee's parenting style on their own approach with their child, emphasizing the importance of understanding and supporting a child's curiosity and exploration rather than trying to control and restrict them. The article calls for a shift in perspective, encouraging adults to consider the well-being and growth of children rather than just seeking convenience for themselves.

item.title: Column | When spicy potatoes ‘trumped’ Trump
item.description: The article tells the story of Tahira, a woman in a peaceful village in Kashmir, whose life is disrupted by the arrival of a television set and the loudness of news presenters. Her patience is further tested when she is introduced to Donald Trump's shouting during the American elections. Despite her initial tolerance, Tahira eventually decides that the television set must be removed from her home, as it disturbs her peace of mind. The article reflects on the idea that events we witness can change us, even if we are not directly involved in them.

item.title: Political Line | Chaos and coalitions
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the realignment of political parties in India, particularly in preparation for the 2024 elections. The author notes that those not aligned with the Congress party are effectively supporting the BJP. Two major alliances were formed recently, one endorsing Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the other vowing to defeat him. The Opposition parties formed an alliance called the Indian National Developmental, Inclusive Alliance (INDIA), indicating their recognition of a need to contest the BJP on nationalist grounds. The NDA gathering, which supported Modi, included parties with little voter base, suggesting an attempt to show that the BJP is not isolated. The article also highlights the focus of both alliances on securing subaltern votes, particularly from OBCs and Dalits. The BJP has successfully captured this space, leaving no visible subaltern leaders or parties. The article further mentions various political equations being disrupted across different states, as parties navigate new alliances and rivalries. It concludes by discussing topics such as sexual violence in Manipur, language instruction in schools, and the question of delimitation in the redrawing of constituency boundaries.

item.title: Political Line | Big Picture: Five vantage points of opposition to Narendra Modi
item.description:
The article discusses the various strands of opposition to the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Prime Minister Narendra Modi in India. It highlights five different vantage points from which opposition groups approach their stance against the BJP.
Firstly, regional elites, such as the DMK in Tamil Nadu and the TMC in West Bengal, can align with either the BJP or the Congress depending on the situation. They negotiate with both parties but currently view the BJP as a bigger threat to their interests.
Secondly, Arvind Kejriwal of the AAP represents an apolitical opposition to the BJP. Although he doesn't oppose the Hindutva agenda, he openly declares war on Prime Minister Modi. Kejriwal focuses on governance as a service delivery platform and can adapt to different ideological settings.
The third vantage point is dominated by middle castes in the Hindutva heartland, such as the Yadavs and Jats. Parties like the SP, RJD, and RLD represent this group, which views both the Congress and BJP with suspicion. They oppose the upper caste prominence within the Hindutva ideology.
Constitutional liberals constitute the fourth vantage point. They focus on principles of constitutional liberalism, individual rights, and the integrity of institutions. While they are opposed to the BJP, they also have reservations about the other opposition vantage points. The Congress and the Left are principal rivals in some states.
Lastly, religious minorities, including Muslims, Sikhs, and Christians, form the fifth vantage point. They may support their own parties or join hands with other opposition groups. Overall, the BJP is seen as a bigger enemy than the Congress, but there are still many contradictions and differences within the opposition.
The interplay between these vantage points will determine the strength and scope of the opposition to the BJP in the upcoming 2024 elections.

item.title: Political Line | Indian battles, global fields
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the controversy surrounding Congress leader Rahul Gandhi's remarks on Indian democracy during his visit to the UK. The BJP and some sections of the media criticized him for speaking about Indian politics abroad. The article highlights that both the BJP and Congress have international wings and receive funds from foreign sources, violating the Foreign Contribution Regulation Act. It also examines the increasing global engagement with Indian politics and the involvement of Indians living abroad in domestic political issues. The article mentions instances of conflicts between different groups in foreign countries and how the BJP is mobilizing support among foreign residents while raising issues related to them with foreign governments. It also touches upon the history of Indian political battles fought overseas and dismisses the BJP's demand for an apology from Rahul Gandhi as a diversionary tactic. The article concludes by stating that Indian politics will be fought not only within India but also globally in the coming years.

item.title: A Red Hat lesson for Elon Musk
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Elon Musk, the new owner of Twitter, plans to make the platform's algorithm open source. This means that the rules governing how content and ads are presented to users will be accessible to the broader developer community. While Musk has not provided an update on when the algorithm will be available to developers, he believes that making it open source will lead to rapid improvement. Twitter, with its relatively large number of highly engaged users, attracted Musk despite its smaller user base and lower profitability compared to Facebook. The article also discusses the history of free and open-source software (FOSS), highlighting Red Hat Inc.'s success in providing open-source software products to enterprise clients. The author suggests that Musk can learn from Red Hat's example and build a new open-source business model for Twitter, but acknowledges that this journey will take time and require Musk to make interest payments on his loans.

item.title: Political Line | Modi will weather the storm
item.description: Couldn't summarize

item.title: Column | On grief and the secret lives of our roots
item.description: The article reflects on the author's experience of feeling a sense of loss and restlessness upon the death of someone they didn't know well. The author describes their relationship with Aunty Nusrat, a family acquaintance who would always attend gatherings and show warmth towards them. They explain how over time, seeing Aunty Nusrat became an expectation and a habit at family events. However, during a cousin's engagement party, the author couldn't find her and later learned that she had passed away. The author reflects on their mixed emotions, feeling restless but not deeply distressed by the loss. They compare their feelings to a painting that has disappeared, leaving only an impression behind. The author discusses their confusion about why they are experiencing these emotions when they weren't close to Aunty Nusrat. In a conversation with Phuphee, they express their surprise and describe themselves as feeling like a fraud. Phuphee responds with an analogy, comparing human connections to trees in a forest, emphasizing that even distant relationships can have an impact on us. She explains that grieving doesn't follow specific rules and that it is normal to feel the way the author does. The author reflects on how Phuphee's words have given them permission to grieve when experiencing loss, whether it be from those close or far away.

item.title: These golden girls | Jennifer Coolidge and Jamie Lee Curtis are acknowledgement of the shining moment that older women are having
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the recent Golden Globe award won by 61-year-old actress Jennifer Coolidge for her role in "The White Lotus." It highlights how this win not only recognizes Coolidge's talent but also represents a golden moment for older women in general. The narrative surrounding older women often focuses on their invisibility, but the article argues that older women are actually living their best lives. Liberated from societal expectations and with financial security, women over 50 are enjoying their time and pursuing their interests. The author reflects on Coolidge's acceptance speech, finding inspiration in her refusal to conform and her embrace of self-expression. The article also mentions another significant moment at the Golden Globe awards when 60-year-old Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh won an award and was celebrated by her colleague Jamie Lee Curtis. The real power of older women is seen not just in their freedom from the male gaze but in the support they find within female friendships. The author concludes by emphasizing that life and work are not zero-sum games, and there are always opportunities for reinvention and growth.

item.title: Political Line | Public Debate on Privacy
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses India's draft Digital Personal Data Protection Bill (DPDP) of 2022, which has sparked intense debate. Critics argue that the bill gives the government too much power to collect data and infringe on individual privacy. The draft emphasizes state authority over data, including trade-related issues. Retired Justice B. N. Srikrishna believes the proposed regulator will lack independence and act as a puppet of the government. However, junior minister for IT, Rajeev Chandrasekhar, disagrees and states that the Data Protection Board will be independent. Despite concerns about state control, some see it as preferable to unregulated private entities having unrestricted access to data. The article also briefly touches on caste dynamics in Bihar, border tensions between India and China, and the elevation of Tamil music by the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu.

item.title: Sinkholes of the heart | Why is a woman’s worth decided by her ability to do certain things?
item.description: This article tells the story of a cow who kept losing her calves, but on her sixth pregnancy, she gave birth to a calf that survived. When the owner slaughtered the cow years later, they discovered that her heart had five holes in it, representing each lost calf. The narrator then recounts an incident at a wedding where a woman named Farhana, who was unable to have children and faced social stigma, showed up uninvited. The other women at the wedding avoided her, causing her to leave. Later, the narrator's companion, Phuphee, reflects on the story of the cow and emphasizes the struggles women face and the need to support and uplift one another. The narrator admits that they didn't fully grasp the message at the time, but later experienced similar pain and heartache in their own life. The article concludes by highlighting the importance of empathy and understanding towards women who face challenges and adversity.

item.title: Political Line | Hardik, Alpesh, Dimple, Kedar: caste tales from Gujarat, U.P., Bihar
item.description:
This article discusses the transformation of the Bharata Janata Party (BJP) under Narendra Modi's leadership and its ability to incorporate different caste identities. The BJP, under Mr. Modi, has managed to restrain dominant castes such as Patels in Gujarat, Marathas in Maharashtra, and Jats in U.P. and Haryana, by aggregating several minor caste groups. Previously, the Patel community controlled the BJP in Gujarat, but Mr. Modi successfully faced challenges from them. Ahead of the 2017 elections, Hardik Patel, a Patel leader, demanded OBC (Other Backward Classes) status for the community and later joined the Congress party. However, in 2022, he switched to the BJP and won as a candidate. Similarly, Alpesh Thakore, an OBC leader who opposed Patel's demand for reservations, also joined and won as a BJP candidate.
The article highlights the conflicting positions on caste quotas held by both Hardik Patel and Alpesh Thakore, who are now BJP MLAs. The BJP managed to bring them together by utilizing state power, and both individuals faced police cases, realizing that opposing the BJP was risky. While some communities within the BJP may not be entirely satisfied with the space and power they hold, the BJP has contained their discontent for now. This situation is comparable to the Jats in Uttar Pradesh, who initially opposed the BJP but ended up voting for the party in large numbers.
The article also touches upon the political dynamics in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, where the Samajwadi Party (SP) and Janata Dal (United) (JDU) claim to champion the cause of OBCs but faced defeat in recent by-elections. The BJP's victory in these bypolls indicates that the alliance between the RJD and JDU is not effectively working on the ground.
In addition to the political analysis, the article briefly mentions the struggle of reviving the Meetei Mayek script in Manipur. The script was replaced by the Bengali script in the 18th century, but language activism is now pushing for its revival.
Overall, the article highlights the BJP's ability to navigate caste dynamics and bring together conflicting interest groups, as well as shedding light on political developments in Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, and Bihar.

item.title: Political Line | The Prime Minister’s political messaging, border disputes, electioneering in Gujarat and more
item.description: The article discusses two recent events in which Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi reached out to the Tamil and Assamese linguistic and cultural groups. In Assam, the BJP has gained significant support, while in Tamil Nadu, the party aims to expand its presence. The Prime Minister addressed a group of Tamils in Varanasi, emphasizing the connection between Kashi and Tamil Nadu and celebrating Tamil culture. This move seeks to address criticism that the BJP undermines Tamil Nadu's cultural identity. Additionally, Mr. Modi participated in an event organized by Himanta Biswa Sarma to commemorate a 16th-century Ahom army general in Assam. By retelling the story of Assamese pride, the Prime Minister reinforces the idea of Assamese exceptionalism and resistance to outside influences. The article also briefly mentions ongoing border disputes between Assam and Meghalaya, as well as Karnataka and Maharashtra. Finally, the author reflects on the changing dynamics of politics in Gujarat, where Gujarati sub-nationalism blended with Hindutva has been weakened by the rise of Modi and Amit Shah in national politics.
